paragraph.htmltext: The following paragraphs give lists of the different types of tests. Note that test procedure, samples, acceptance, will depend on the application in which the module is used and the characteristics of the module

System safety analysis

The device under test shall be conducted to an analysis of potential hazards to determine events that could lead to hazardous conditions and to verify that all of them are identified and addressed through design or other means. Interface with the vehicle system and access by first responders and service personnel needs to be included in the analysis.

Performance and reliability tests

These tests are related to normal operating conditions and are indented to ensure a safe battery system under typical vehicle environmental used conditions. The following test are described in standards:
• Vibration tests: This condition simulates a vibration environment which a battery system will likely experience during its life.
• Salt spray test: determines the electrical energy storage assembly’s ability to safely withstand anticipated exposure to a salt mist
• Humidity and moisture exposure: This condition simulates a temperature/humidity environment which a battery system will likely experience during its life.
• Thermal shock: This condition simulates a rapid temperature change environment which a battery system will likely experience during its life.

• Thermal cycling: determines the electrical energy storage assembly’s ability to withstand exposure to rapidly changing environments such as when the vehicle is entering or exiting a heated garage after being in a cold environment, or during transport etc. without evidence of damage that could lead to a hazardous event
• Temperature test: determine whether or not the modules and their cells are being maintained within their specified limits during maximum charge and discharge conditions of the pack
• Failure of Cooling/Thermal Stability System Test: evaluate the electrical energy storage assembly’s ability to safely withstand a failure in the cooling/thermal stability system.
• Energy and capacity at different temperatures and discharge rates

• Imbalance charging test: determine whether or not a batter pacjk with series connected modules can maintain the cells/modules within their specified operating parameters if it becomes imbalances
  • Dielectric voltage withstand test: evaluation of electrical spacing and insulation at hazardous voltage circuits of the pack
  • Isolation resistance test: determine if the insulation provides adequate isolation of hazardous voltage circuits from accessible conductive parts of the electric energy storage assembly and that it is non-hygroscopic
  • Continuity Test: evaluates the continuity of the protective grounding system of the electric energy storage assembly.

• Calendar life test
  • Module controls verification test
  • Operating set point stability test
  • Hybrid pulse power characterization test
  • Reference performance test
  • System-level combined life verification test

Abuse tests

During the design and development of a battery pack, abuse tests should be executed to determine the response of the module and control systems to conditions or events which are beyond their normal operating range. These conditions may arise as a result of operator negligence, vehicle accidents, device or system defects, poorly informed users or mechanics, failure of specific control and support hardware, or transportation/handling incidents or accidents.

The following test procedures for abuse tests are described in standards (SAE J2464, … )

Note:

  • Some standards state that the test can be performed on cell level, module level and/or pack level.
  • Test procedure can depend on the type of application in which the pack is used: high power application or high energy application

Hazardous substance monitoring tests

These tests measure amounts of hazardous substances released when the pack container vents or is compromised during an abusive event.

For these tests the mounting and support shall be as similar as possible to the manufacturer’s recommended installations requirements for mechanical shock and vibration tests. The following tests are defined :
• High temperature hazard test or over temperature protection
• Passive propagation resistance test (test evaluate the ability to withstand a single cell thermal runaway event so that a thermal runaway event does not propagate to adjacent cells.)

Test procedures for protection against electric shock

The tests to verify the protection measures shall in principle be performed on each high voltage electric circuit on the vehicle, when the charge coupler is disconnected. The following tests are defined:

  • Isolation resistance measurements
  • Withstand voltage test
  • Continuity test for potential equalization
